speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these episodes of unresponsiveness started happening? Were they sudden or did they come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it just started a month ago, and they seem to come out of nowhere. I'll be playing, drawing, or watching TV, and then I just... freeze up for a few minutes. It's like my brain just stops working for a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens during these episodes? Do you experience any pain, numbness, or tingling sensations, and do you regain consciousness immediately after they pass?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels like my face gets all stiff and my eyes get really wide, and I just stare off into space for a few minutes. I don't really remember what's happening, and when it's over, I just kind of... snap back. I'm usually really confused and feel really tired afterwards, like I just ran a marathon or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: How often do these episodes occur, and do you find that they're more frequent at certain times of the day or in response to specific triggers, such as stress or certain activities?

speaker: Patient
text: "They happen about 3 or 4 times a week, and I don't think they're triggered by anything in particular. My brother said he saw me doing some hand gestures during one episode, but I don't remember what I was doing. I just kind of... acted out, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes that your brother witnessed? Did you have any unusual movements or behaviors during that time, and did you regain consciousness immediately after the episode? Also, have you experienced any other symptoms besides these episodes of unresponsiveness, such as seizures, headaches, or changes in your appetite or sleep patterns?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my brother saw me making some weird hand gestures, like I was trying to say something, but I don't know what it was. And when it was all over, I just kind of... collapsed and fell over onto my side. It took me a while to get back to myself, like I was in a fog or something. And, um, I don't really remember anything about it afterwards, but my brother said I was really confused and didn't make sense for a while."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family history? Have any of your relatives experienced similar episodes or neurological conditions? "Uh, my grandma had some kind of seizures when she was younger, but I don't think it was anything like this. And my brother's always been a bit of a worrier, so I'm sure he's just trying to help, but I don't know if it's really relevant."

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think it's really relevant, but... my mom's been noticing that my brother's been acting really nervous about it, and he's always been a bit of a worrier. But, I don't know, maybe that's just because he's my brother?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and routine? Do you engage in any activities that involve manual dexterity, such as playing musical instruments, typing, or playing sports? Also, have you noticed any other unusual physical symptoms besides the episodes of unresponsiveness, such as tremors, weakness, or difficulty with speech or swallowing?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I like playing video games and watching cartoons, and I'm pretty good at drawing and coloring. I also like building with Legos and playing with my friends outside. I don't think any of those things make the episodes happen, though. And, um, I don't really feel any weird sensations or anything like that. I just feel really tired and confused afterwards, like I said."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your overall health and well-being? Have you experienced any other symptoms such as fever, headache, or joint pain that could be related to these episodes? And, just to clarify, you mentioned your brother witnessed one of the episodes. Did he notice anything unusual about the episode, such as the duration or the intensity of the unresponsiveness?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I've been feeling pretty good overall, just a little tired and confused sometimes. I don't think I've ever had a fever or a headache that lasted for a long time, but I do get headaches sometimes when I hit my head on something. And, um, my brother said the episode he saw was pretty long, like 3 or 4 minutes, and I was just staring off into space the whole time, but I don't know what I was thinking about."

speaker: Doctor

Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Have you noticed any changes in your sleep quality or duration

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh, I sleep okay, I guess. I mean, I usually go to bed around 7 or 8 and wake up around 6 or 7 in the morning. I don't really remember anything weird happening during sleep, but sometimes I have trouble falling asleep because I'm just really tired from the episodes. And, um, sometimes I have nightmares, but that's not really related to the episodes, I think."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request some test results to help narrow down the possible causes of your episodes. Can you please get a blood test done to check for any abnormal levels of electrolytes, such as potassium or sodium? Also, I'd like to request an electroencephalogram (EEG) to see if there are any abnormal brain wave patterns. Additionally, I'd like to perform a physical examination to assess your overall condition. Can you please stand up and walk slowly for me, so I can observe your gait and balance?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll try. *walks slowly and carefully, trying not to stumble* I don't really feel like I'm doing anything wrong, but I'll try my best. *pauses and looks around* Do I have to do anything else? *looks down at feet* I don't really feel any weird sensations or anything like that, but I do feel a little...off afterwards, like my legs are all wobbly or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're doing your best to cooperate. I'd like to ask a few more questions before we proceed with the tests. Can you tell me more about your brother's reaction to these episodes? Has he noticed anything unusual about your behavior or movements during these episodes, or has he expressed any concerns about your safety? Also, I'd like to request some additional test results. Can you please get a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) to check for any abnormal levels of electrolytes, such as potassium or sodium? Additionally, I'd like to request an MRI of your brain to look for any structural abnormalities that could be contributing to these episodes.

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, my brother's been really worried about it. He's always trying to help me remember what's happening, but I don't really remember anything, so it's hard for him to figure out what's going on. He's just trying to make sure I'm okay, I think."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like your brother is trying to be supportive, but it's understandable that he's concerned. Can you tell me more about your brother's behavior during these episodes? Does he try to intervene or try to get you to respond in any way, or does he just let you be and wait for you to come back to yourself?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my brother tries to stay with me and talk to me during the episodes, but I don't really hear him or respond. He just kind of... stays there with me, like, holding my hand or something, until I come back to myself. And when it's over, he's always like, 'Are you okay? What happened?' But I don't really know, so it's hard for him to understand what's going on."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask a few more questions about your brother's behavior during these episodes. You mentioned that he tries to stay with you and talk to you, but you don't really respond.
